sect1.title: 42 Yersiniaceae*

para.phrase: LUKE C. KINGRY, LORI GLADNEY, AND JEANNINE M. PETERSEN

sect1.para: The familyYersiniaceae includes two well-known pathogenic genera, Serratia and Yersinia, and multiple other genera which inhabit a wide range of ecological niches. Members of the genus Serratia, which are found in the environment, encompass species that are important causes of health care-associated infections. Serratia marcescens is the Serratia species most often isolated from clinical specimens and can cause urinary tract infections, pneumonia, bloodstream infections, endocarditis, and wound infections. Within the genus Yersinia, three species, Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, Y. enterocolitica, and Y. pestis, are of primary clinical significance. Y. pseudotuberculosis and Y. enterocolitica infections occur after the ingestion of contaminated food or water and clinical manifestations include gastroenteritis, mesenteric adenitis, and reactive arthritis. Y. pestis, the etiologic agent of plague, is transmitted to humans by the bite of an infected flea and results in life-threatening illness, with mortality rates of 50 to 100% if untreated. Y. pestis, the notorious cause of three major pandemics, including the Black Death, is classified as a tier 1 select agent, one of six bacterial agents considered to present the greatest risk of deliberate misuse. Other genera in this family include Chania, Ewingella, Gibbsiella, Rahnella, and Rouxiella, which are widely distributed throughout the environment and of more limited or no clinical significance. This chapter primarily focuses on the taxonomy, detection, and identification of Serratia and Yersinia, with other family members also discussed.

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The familyYersiniaceae belongs to the order Enterobacterales and the gamma subclass of proteobacteria (1). Since publication of the previous edition of this Manual, taxonomic changes have expanded the Yersiniaceae to include the genera Chania, Ewingella, Gibbsiella, Rahnella, Rouxiella, and Serratia along with the type genus, Yersinia (1, 2). Genome-to-genome relatedness and phylogenetic trees based on core proteins or ribosomal proteins demonstrate that the family Yersiniaceae forms a distinct cluster within the Enterobacterales. Family members can be distinguished from other Enterobacterales members by conserved signature indels in the protein TetR family transcriptional regulator and a hypothetical protein (1). Between the different genera of Yersiniaceae, 16S rRNA gene sequence identity ranges from 90.4% to 95.5% (1).

The genusYersinia includes three species of clinical significance—Yersinia pestis, Y. pseudotuberculosis, and Y. enterocolitica—as well as 28 other officially recognized Yersinia species (www.bacterio.net/genus/yersinia) (Table 1). All Yersinia genomes are composed of a single chromosome. The pathogenic Yersinia species also harbor a <75-kb virulence plasmid (3). Two additional plasmids (pMT1 and pCP1) are found in Y. pestis, with some Y. pseudotuberculosis strains harboring an additional plasmid (4, 5). The genomes of Y. pestis and Y. pseudotuberculosis share a high degree of genetic similarity; 75% of the 3,974 predicted genes in Y. pseudotuberculosis show ≥97% identity to homologs in Y. pestis (6).

The genusSerratia includes 23 officially recognized species, including 9 species which have been isolated from clinical specimens (www.bacterio.net/genus/serratia) (Tables 2 and 3). Serratia marcescens is the species most commonly associated with human infections (7). Serratia genomes are composed of a single circular chromosome. Plasmid composition is variable among Serratia species and strains, with little to no similarity between them.
The generaChania and Ewingella each comprise a single species, whereas Gibbsiella, Rahnella, and Rouxiella consist of 3, 7 and 4 species, respectively (www.bacterio.net) (Tables 2 and 3).

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE AGENT
sect2.para: Yersiniaceae members are Gram-negative rods that are non-spore-forming, oxidase-negative, catalase-positive facultative anaerobes which display nonfastidious growth (1). They do not produce hydrogen disulfide. The majority of Yersiniaceae range in size from about 0.5 to 0.9 μm in diameter and 1 to 3 μm in length. Chania is the largest member of the family, with rods 3 to 4 μm by 7 to 9 μm in size. Growth parameters for this family include temperatures from 4 to 43°C. Motility is variable. Characteristics of selected family members are listed in Tables 1 and 3.

Pigment production is restricted toSerratia. Some strains of S. marcescens and most S. rubidaea and S. plymuthica strains produce prodigiosin, a red pigment (7). The pigment may be red, pink, magenta, or orange, depending on culture conditions. Serratia odorifera, S. ficaria, and some strains of S. rubidaea produce a potato-like odor due to the production of alkyl-methoxypyrazines (7).

sect1.title: Yersinia
sect1.para: Among the pathogenicYersinia species, Y. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis are motile at temperatures below 30°C due to uniformly distributed or peripolar flagella (Table 1). Lipopolysaccharide is a major component of the outer membrane of members of the genus Yersinia (8). The lipopolysaccharide of Y. pseudotuberculosis and Y. enterocolitica (smooth forms) is complete (lipid A-oligosaccharide core-O antigen polysaccharide), and O-chain variation within these species has enabled serodiscrimination of O groups (8–10). In contrast, Y. pestis produces R (rough)-type lipopolysaccharide, limited to a short carbohydrate chain and lacking the ability to produce high-acyl forms of lipid A at 37°C (11).

The pathogenicYersinia species possess a common and genetically conserved 68- to 75-kb virulence plasmid termed pCD1 in Y. pestis and pYV in Y. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis. This plasmid encodes components of the Yersinia type III secretion system (12–14). Two plasmids unique to Y. pestis encode proteins important for its utilization of a flea vector and its ability to cause disease. The 50- to 120-kb plasmid (pMT1) encodes the fraction 1 antigen (F1) (4, 12). F1 forms a capsule-like structure on the bacterial surface with antiphagocytic properties that enables dissemination and replication of the bacteria (4). F1 is expressed only at temperatures of >33°C. Plasminogen activator, encoded by the 10-kb plasmid (pCP1), is a surface protease that activates mammalian plasminogen and degrades complement; it is important for dissemination in mouse models of bubonic and pneumonic disease (4, 12, 15). All three plasmids are required for full Y. pestis virulence.

sect1.title: Serratia
sect1.para: All species within the genusSerratia are motile (16, 17). Some strains of S. marcescens and most S. rubidaea and S. plymuthica strains produce a red pigment, prodigiosin, which may appear throughout the entire colony or only as a red center or margin (Table 3). S. marcescens produces two components hemolysin, ShlA and ShlB, which causes cytotoxicity affecting red blood cells, epithelial cells and fibroblasts (7). The ability of these proteins to cause damage usually depends on adherence to eukaryotic cells. Quorum sensing and biofilm production have been reported for S. marcescens and S. plymuthica (7). S. marcescens is frequently resistant to multiple antimicrobials. Many S. marcescens strains carry both chromosomally encoded and plasmid-mediated resistance determinants for several different types of antimicrobials (7, 16).

sect1.title: Ewingella, Rahnella, and Rouxiella
sect1.para: Ewingella and Rahnella species are motile. Ewingella americana strains display uniformly distributed flagella, and Rahnella species have a polar flagellum. Intrinsic antimicrobial resistance to cefaclor, oxacillin, and erythromycin is common among E. americana strains. Rouxiella species are nonmotile, and colonies are lemon yellow (18).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: TheYersiniaceae are widely distributed throughout the environment and transmitted to humans via arthropod bites, contact with infected animals, ingestion of contaminated food or water, or exposure to hospital environments and medical procedures.

sect1.title: Y. pestis
sect1.para: Y. pestis exists naturally in enzootic cycles between wild rodents and their fleas. Humans are exposed to Y. pestis most commonly through flea bites but also through contact with tissues of infected animals or inhaling infectious respiratory droplets. Since 1970, >50% of human cases in the United States had exposures to animals that may have led to infection (19). Most cases of human plague are sporadic and occur in rural areas. Human risk is greatest when epizootics cause high mortality in rodent populations, thereby forcing fleas to seek alternative hosts, including humans. Although many species of fleas parasitize rodents, transmission of plague is classically associated with the rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis) (4).

Worldwide, 1,000 to 2,000 human cases of plague are reported to the World Health Organization annually. Of these, a majority are reported from Africa. In the United States, from 2000 through 2019, 125 plague cases were reported, with 12 deaths (https://www.cdc.gov/plague/maps/index.html). Over this time, an average of 5 human plague cases were reported annually (range, 1 to 17 cases per year). Locally acquired human plague occurs in the western United States, with more than 80% occurring in New Mexico, Arizona, Colorado, and California (20).

Human-to-human transmission can occur with pneumonic plague and therefore poses a special public health threat (21). Most transmissions are to family members and health care providers through close-contact inhalation of particles from infected people who are coughing bloody sputum. Since 1924, there has been only a single suspected case of human-to-human transmission in the United States (22). Analysis of primary pneumonic cases in the United States indicates that a majority of patients fail to transmit the disease to other people, even in the absence of antimicrobial treatment or prophylaxis (23). Control measures include physical distancing, isolation, quarantine, and simple barrier precautions (23).

sect1.title: Enteropathogenic Yersinia
sect1.para: Y. enterocolitica is a heterogeneous species comprising multiple bioserotypes that exhibit variability in pathogenicity to humans and other animals (5). The Y. enterocolitica bioserotypes most often associated with human illness are 1B/O:8, 2/O:5,27, 2/O:9, 3/O:3, and 4/O:3, with bioserotype 4/O:3 predominating as the most common type in the United States and Europe (24, 25). Biotype 1B is generally restricted to North America and Japan, whereas biotype 3 is predominantly isolated in Japan and China (24). Disease incidence is higher in temperate and cold countries. Transmission occurs primarily via the fecal-oral route; organisms are ingested via food or water contaminated by feces of infected animals. Organisms are found in the gastrointestinal tracts of many animal species, most commonly swine, rodents, and dogs. Wild boars are a reservoir of Y. enterocolitica in Europe and Japan (26). Food products, particularly unpasteurized and pasteurized milk, vegetables, and undercooked meats such as chitterlings (27), and retail frozen foods (28, 29) have been found to contain these organisms. Chitterlings are a frequent cause of illness in young children with a Yersinia infection, but they can be prepared safely (https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/chitlins.html). In North America, Y. enterocolitica bioserotype 1B/O:8 has been responsible for several outbreaks associated with milk and dairy products (30, 31).

Y. pseudotuberculosis is found in the environment (soil and water) and in a diverse group of wild animal species. The organism has a wide distribution in countries with cold climates; it is more common in northern Europe and Asia, including Japan. Y. pseudotuberculosis is not frequently isolated in the United States or Europe (25, 32, 33). In France, Y. pseudotuberculosis was isolated from only 6% of culture-confirmed yersiniosis cases occurring over a 50-year period (25). Y. pseudotuberculosis serotypes associated with human illness include O:1 and O:3, isolated in Europe, and O:4 and O:5, isolated in Japan (24). The main reservoirs for the organism are rodents, rabbits, wild boars, deer, and wild birds (34, 35). The mode of transmission of Y. pseudotuberculosis is via ingestion of contaminated food (vegetables and meat) or water contaminated by animal reservoirs or by contact with infected animals.

A majority of yersinosis cases are attributed toY. enterocolitica. Between 1996 and 2007, the average annual incidences of Y. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis infections in the United States were 3.5 and 0.04 cases per 1,000,000 people, respectively (32). During 2019, the overall incidence for yersiniosis in the United States was 1.4 cases per 1,000,000 people, representing a 153% increase compared to 2016 to 2018 due to the increased use of culture-independent diagnostic tests (CIDTs) (32, 36). In the European Union, yersiniosis was the fourth most reported zoonosis in humans in 2019, with 7,048 confirmed cases reported (33). The overall notification rate of 1.7 cases per 100,000 people remained stable from 2015 to 2019. Y. enterocolitica caused the majority of human infections (99%) (37).

sect1.title: Serratia
sect1.para: Water appears to be a natural environment for severalSerratia species associated with human infections, including S. marcescens, S. fonticola, S. grimesii, S. liquefaciens, S. plymuthica, and S. rubidaea (7). S. marcescens, S. grimesii, S. liquefaciens, and S. quinivorans are also associated with soil.

Serratia species are notorious health care-associated pathogens. Transmission is predominantly from person to person, but contaminated medical apparatuses, intravenous fluids, and other solutions are also implicated in transmission and infection. Indwelling catheters, particularly for urinary tract infections, serve as a primary reservoir for transmission via hospital personnel (7). In children, the gastrointestinal tract is a common source of infection. Outbreaks in health care settings are often insidious, occurring over long periods, and may subside and peak several times before recognition and infection control efforts contain them. Indeed, one of the hallmarks of nosocomial outbreaks due to S. marcescens is multidrug-resistant strains. Outbreaks due to S. marcescens have also been reported in long-term care facilities (38). Community-acquired infections include S. marcescens contact lens-induced keratitis, endophthalmitis, and conjunctivitis.

In a survey of ICU-acquired infections in European countries in 2017,Serratia species represented 5.3%, 3.4%, and 1.4% of reported pneumonia, bloodstream, and urinary tract infections, respectively (39). A 2015 survey of health care-associated infections in 10 U.S. states found that Serratia species accounted for 1% of all health care infections, including pneumonia and surgical site infections (40).

sect1.title: Ewingella and Rahnella
sect1.para: E. americana is an opportunistic and a rare cause of human infection. It can survive in citrate solution and water. Infections have been reported in the United States and Europe (41, 42). The organism infects at-risk or predisposed people, such as patients with prolonged hospitalization, those in the postoperative period (particularly after cardiovascular surgery), those with indwelling catheters, and individuals with kidney failure and peritoneal-dialysis-associated peritonitis (43).

Rahnella species are widely distributed in the environment and have been isolated from freshwater, soil, beetles, and trees (Table 2). Rahnella aquatilis is associated with freshwater sources and rarely isolated from humans. Infections ascribed to this organism include infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent patients resulting from infusions (44, 45). Only a single human infection due to R. variigena has been documented, with the type strain for this species being isolated from a human burn sample in the United States (46).

sect1.title: Chania, Gibbsiella, and Rouxiella
sect1.para: Members of the generaChania, Gibbsiella, and Rouxiella are associated only with environmental sources (Table 2).

sect1.title: Y. pestis
sect1.para: Plague is a severe febrile illness that is often fatal without prompt and appropriate antimicrobial treatment. There are three major forms of plague: bubonic, pneumonic, and septicemic (47). Bubonic plague, the most common clinical presentation, is due to bite of an infected flea (20). After a 2- to 6-day incubation period, sudden onset of fever, headache, chills, and weakness and one or more swollen, tender, and painful lymph nodes (buboes) occurs. Pneumonic plague can be a secondary complication of bubonic plague or can be a primary infection following direct inhalation of aerosolized organisms. After an incubation period of 1 to 3 days, symptoms include fever, headache, weakness, and a rapidly developing pneumonia with shortness of breath, chest pain, cough, and sometimes bloody or watery mucus (47). Pneumonic plague is the most serious form of the disease and is the only form that spreads from person to person (by infectious droplets). Septicemic plague occurs when the organisms are introduced directly to the bloodstream without localizing in regional lymph nodes. Patients develop fever, chills, extreme weakness, abdominal pain, shock, and possibly bleeding into the skin and other organs.

Mortality among untreated septicemic and pneumonic cases approaches 100%, and that among treated cases can exceed 50%. The case fatality rate for untreated bubonic plague is 50 to 60% (20). From 1990 to 2010, the overall mortality reported for Y. pestis infections in the United States was 11%. It is hard to assess the mortality rate of plague in developing countries, because relatively few cases are reliably diagnosed and reported to health authorities. The WHO cites a global mortality rate of 18% for the period of 2010 to 2015 (48).

The most common form of disease due toY. enterocolitica is gastroenteritis associated with the consumption of contaminated food or water. It is not unusual to isolate Y. enterocolitica from raw meats, including beef, lamb, pork, and chicken. The organism has also been found as a contaminant of cooked, prepackaged deli meat and unpasteurized milk products. Most strains isolated from human food sources are of the nonpathogenic bioserotypes. Carriage of the pathogenic bioserotypes of Y. enterocolitica is more common in swine; therefore, consumption or handling of raw or undercooked pork, especially intestines (e.g., chitterlings), is the main risk factor for gastroenteritis (27, 49, 50). Transfusion-related Y. enterocolitica infections due to contaminated red blood cells have been reported. Since the organism can survive and multiply at refrigeration temperatures, donated blood contaminated with small numbers of organisms from an asymptomatic person can transmit infection to the transfused patient (51, 52).

Severity of disease is related to the bioserotype and can range from self-limited gastroenteritis to mesenteric lymphadenitis, which can be misdiagnosed as appendicitis, and terminal ileitis, mimicking Crohn disease (53). Outbreaks are sometimes detected as a sudden increase in appendectomies due to mistaken diagnoses of appendicitis. Imaging can help diagnose appendicitis and identify alternative diagnoses for right lower quadrant pain (54). Young children most commonly develop gastroenteritis and present with fever, watery diarrhea (occasionally bloody and severe), and abdominal pain following consumption of food contaminated by Y. enterocolitica. Although symptoms typically resolve within approximately 7 days, patients can carry the organism in their gastrointestinal tracts for several months. Organisms can migrate out of the gut via the lymphatics into local lymph nodes. An uncommon complication of gastroenteritis is septicemia. People at high risk for septicemia include the elderly and immunocompromised patients, particularly those with underlying metabolic diseases that are associated with iron overload, cancer, liver disease, and steroid therapy. Reactive arthritis is an uncommon sequela of Y. enterocolitica infection (55). Other less common sequelae associated with Y. enterocolitica infection include erythema nodosum, septic arthritis, and infective endocarditis (56, 57).

Y. pseudotuberculosis usually produces a self-limiting disease; infections, while rare, occur most commonly in children and young adults. Symptoms caused by Y. pseudotuberculosis infection include abdominal pain and fever. The abdominal pain is often in the right lower quadrant, and the resulting mesenteric lymphadenitis may mimic appendicitis (54). Diarrhea is uncommon. Y. pseudotuberculosis can also cause terminal ileitis, mimicking Crohn’s disease (58, 59). Septicemia generally occurs in immunocompromised patients; patients with iron overload states such as liver cirrhosis or hemochromatosis are at risk of sepsis (60). Reported sequelae of Y. pseudotuberculosis infection include reactive arthritis and erythema nodosum (61, 62). Y. pseudotuberculosis strains possessing the superantigenic toxin YPMa are the causative agent of Far East scarlet fever-like, a severe systemic inflammatory disease, in Japan and Russia (63).

The lack of classic virulence markers, i.e., the 70-kb virulence plasmid, in the otherYersinia species has led to their general classification as nonpathogenic. Multiple species, including Y. artesiana, Y. alsatica, Y. frederiksenii, Y. intermedia, Y. kristensenii, Y. mollaretii, Y. occitanica, Y. vastinensis, and Y. wautersii have been isolated from stool specimens (64, 65). In a study of ~20,000 Yersinia strains recovered from human, animal, environmental (water, sewage), and food sources over a 50-year period in France, nonpathogenic Yersinia strains were more frequently isolated from food and environmental sources than enteropathogenic Yersinia, which were more commonly isolated from animal sources. Given the abundance of nonpathogenic Yersinia species in nature, it was postulated that they frequently transit the human gut (25).

sect1.title: Serratia
sect1.para: Serratia species are of relatively low virulence and do not commonly infect healthy humans, but they frequently colonize or infect immunocompromised or critically ill hospitalized patients, particularly in settings such as intensive care units (16). S. marcescens is the most common clinical species worldwide; with other members of the genus occasionally isolated from clinical samples (7). S. marcescens causes pneumonia and other respiratory diseases, urinary tract infections, many wound infections, bloodstream infections, including endocarditis, and central nervous system infections, including meningitis (7).

S. liquefaciens, the second most commonly isolated Serratia species, is infrequently isolated from human clinical samples (7). Infections are broad and similar to those caused by other opportunistic pathogens including respiratory and urinary tract infections, wound infections, and septicemia in patients with contaminated blood product transfusions (7). Isolation of S. rubidaea, S. fonticola, S. ficaria. S. grimesii, S. quinivorans, S. odorifera, and S. plymuthica from clinical samples occurs only rarely, and its clinical significance is often unclear (7).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Clinical laboratories should be aware of the sentinel-level clinical microbiology laboratory guidelines for suspected biological threat agents outlined by the American Society for Microbiology (LRN Sentinel Level Clinical Laboratory Protocols [https://asm.org/Articles/CPHMC/Laboratory-Response-Network-LRN-Sentinel-Level-C]). In the United States, Y. pestis is classified as a tier 1 select agent. In the European Union and Russia, Y. pestis is classified as very-high-threat group and group 1, respectively (66). To receive or possess Y. pestis strains in the United States, laboratories must be registered with the federal Select Agent Program (https://www.selectagents.gov). Clinical laboratories are exempt from the registration requirement with the Select Agent Program as pertains to conducting diagnostic testing, as the laboratory destroys or transfers any confirmed agent within 7 days of identification.

All procedures for samples suspected of containingY. pestis should be performed in a facility with a minimum biosafety level of 2 (BSL-2). BSL-2 practices, containment equipment, and facilities are recommended for all activities involving the handling of potentially infectious clinical materials (https://www.cdc.gov/labs/pdf/SF__19_308133-A_BMBL6_00-BOOK-WEB-final-3.pdf). BSL-3 practices, containment equipment and facilities are recommended for processes with increased risk for creating an aerosol, including any handling of cultures. Y. pestis is a documented laboratory hazard. Laboratory-acquired cases of plague, several fatal, have been reported in the United States and have occurred in research and clinical laboratory settings (20, 23, 67).

Y. pestis strains lacking either the pgm locus (a 102-kb chromosomal region encoding yersiniabactin iron transport, the Hms biofilm, and other systems) or the 60- to 85-kb virulence plasmid are exempt from select agent regulations in the United States (www.selectagents.gov). Y. pestis strains lacking the pgm locus, while attenuated, can cause illness in some circumstances. A fatal laboratory-acquired infection due to an attenuated Δpgm Y. pestis strain occurred in a researcher with undiagnosed hemochromatosis (67). Y. pestis strains lacking the virulence plasmid are considered avirulent (68).

ForY. pestis, preferred specimens for direct detection are dependent on the clinical presentation; lymph node aspirates and blood are recommended in bubonic presentations, blood in septicemic presentations, and respiratory samples (e.g., sputum) and blood in pneumonic presentations. Because bubonic plague patients may shed organisms into the blood intermittently, particularly in the initial stages of illness, the sensitivity of blood cultures may be limited in early disease. Tissue samples from autopsy specimens, including lymph node, spleen, liver, and lung, can be utilized for testing. For indirect detection for all clinical presentations, serum samples can be tested for antibodies to Y. pestis. A first blood specimen should be collected as early in the course of infection as possible, followed by a second specimen taken in the convalescent period (at least 14 days apart and preferably 3 to 4 weeks after symptom onset).

For transport, Cary-Blair medium and swabs are useful for preservation of viable organisms. Survival ofY. pestis after storage for 96 h at ambient room temperature in Amies medium has been demonstrated (69). ESwabs® have not been specifically tested for use with Y. pestis but may be suitable for transport because they are based on Amies medium. To minimize loss in viability, specimens should be sent to the laboratory immediately. Freezing of samples is not recommended for specimens intended for culture because of lysis of live bacteria upon thawing. Serum separation from blood should take place as soon as possible.

The appropriate specimens for culture ofY. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis are stool, blood, and lymph nodes, depending on the disease form suspected. Swabs should be transported to the laboratory at 4°C in Cary-Blair, Amies, or Stuart’s medium. Stool specimens can also be placed in transport medium and should be maintained at 4°C if transport is expected to take longer than 4 h. If food is suspected as the source of an outbreak, the local health department should be involved in the processing of such specimens. Food should be maintained at 4°C and transported as soon as possible.

ForSerratia species, appropriate specimens include blood, wound, tissue, and respiratory specimens. Serratia isolates can be shipped on nutrient agar or nonselective similar media, such as tryptic soy agar (TSA) or heart infusion agar.

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: Yersinia species are small (1 to 2 by 0.5 μm) Gram-negative bacilli that appear either as single cells when slides are prepared from agar plates or as pairs or short chains when slides are prepared from liquid media. Wright, Giemsa, and Wayson stains performed on peripheral blood or tissue may reveal the bipolar staining of Y. pestis (https://asm.org/ASM/media/Policy-and-Advocacy/LRN/Y-pestis-fixed-figures.pdf); however, this is not a unique feature of Y. pestis and may not always be evident. Bipolar staining of Y. pestis cells is not typically observed by Gram staining. Cells of Serratia, Ewingella, and Rahnella are also small Gram-negative rods with sizes of 0.9 to 2.0 by 0.5 to 0.8 μm, 0.6 by 1 to 1.8 μm, and 0.5 to 0.7 by 2 to 3 μm, respectively.

sect1.title: Antigen Detection and Serologic Tests
sect1.para: The capsular F1 antigen is specific forY. pestis. Numerous tests have been developed for rapid detection of both the F1 antigen and antibodies to this antigen due to the strong and specific immune response to this antigen (70). F1 antigen capture-based immunochromatographic lateral-flow assays are used in several countries. An analysis of an F1 antigen lateral-flow assay in Madagascar demonstrated 100% accuracy for recovered Y. pestis isolates and approximately 70% accuracy for clinical specimens (70). Commercially available lateral flow tests in the United States include Yersinia pestis (F1) Smart II (New Horizons Diagnostics), Plague BioThreat Alert test strips (Tetracore), and BADD Plague (ADVNT Technologies). These tests are intended to detect Y. pestis in environmental samples and are not for clinical diagnosis of plague or identification of Y. pestis isolates. Tissue specimens fixed in formalin can be tested via an immunohistochemical stain that utilizes a monoclonal antibody to the F1 capsular antigen of Y. pestis (71). Reference testing is available at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Serology can play a role in the diagnosis of plague if the organism is not recovered in culture or in epidemiologic studies in areas where plague is endemic. Given the short incubation period for plague and the high mortality for untreated illness, serology has limited value in clinical management. Most patients infected withY. pestis require 1 to 2 weeks to develop a detectable antibody response. Studies have shown persistence of anti-F1 antibodies in people with past Y. pestis infection; antibody to F1 was shown in 88% and 70% of patients infected within the previous 5 and 10 years, respectively (72). Serologic methods, such as passive hemagglutination, can be used to test both human and animal samples.

Serology can be used as an adjunct in the diagnosis of disease due toY. enterocolitica or Y. pseudotuberculosis. Antibody is detectable within the first week of illness and returns to normal levels 3 to 6 months later. The specificity of serologic assays ranges from 82 to 95% due to cross-reactivity between the two species and with Brucella and Vibrio species, as well as Borrelia burgdorferi, Chlamydia pneumoniae, and some Escherichia coli serogroups. A disadvantage of serologic assays that detect antibodies to Y. enterocolitica O antigens is that these antibodies are often found in healthy subjects due to the frequency of exposure to nonpathogenic serotypes. Antibody to outer membrane proteins (Yops) that are present only in virulent strains of Y. enterocolitica may be more helpful. In a small study of healthy blood donors, immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibody to Yops was 97% specific for acute infection (73). Testing of blood donors for anti-Yop IgA in New Zealand, where a high incidence of Y. enterocolitica gastroenteritis is reported, showed promise in preventing transfusion-related infections (74). IgM-, IgA-, and IgG-specific antibody reactivity against Yops in Western immunoblot formats has been correlated with clinical presentation and sequelae (75).

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) can be utilized for the detection of DNA in patient specimens. ForY. pestis, real-time NAATs are often directed against the plasminogen activator gene (pla) or caf1 gene, which encodes the F1 antigen; both targets are located on Y. pestis-specific plasmids. A pla gene, with high homology to the Y. pestis pla gene (98.8% similarity), has been identified in rats and some Enterobacteriaceae, and thus, stand-alone NAATs targeting the pla gene are not recommended for diagnosis of Y. pestis infection (76–78). For PCR diagnosis of plague, a combination of at least two gene targets, with both assays positive, is recommended by the WHO (79). To date, validation of Y. pestis NAATs using human clinical samples is limited. When real-time (5′ nuclease) PCR assays directed against both caf1 and pla were tested using bubo aspirates from 47 patients with culture-confirmed infection, 100% correlation between culture and PCR was demonstrated (80). Real-time NAATs for rapid diagnosis of Y. pestis infection are available in Laboratory Response Network (LRN) reference laboratories. The utility of these assays for diagnosis of Y. pestis infection (both pneumonic and bubonic presentations) has been described (22, 81). A two-target NAAT-based system has been cleared by the FDA for detection of Y. pestis (www.biofiredefense.com/jbaids/; https://www.biofiredefense.com/products/biofire-filmarray-biosurveillance-system/#FAbiothreat). However, this system is not commercially available. A newer nucleic acid detection method is pathogen identification by shotgun metagenomics, which is based on untargeted next-generation sequencing (NGS), or massively parallel sequencing of the genomic content of a sample. Y. pestis was reported to be detected by one such test (82). As this method has not been fully evaluated for Yersinia species, diagnoses should be confirmed by reference methods whenever possible.

NAATs have also been used as a sensitive method to detect small numbers ofY. enterocolitica in foodstuff (83), as well as in stored red blood cells to prevent transfusion reactions (84). Use of multiplex NAATs containing primer sets for detection of up to five virulence genes allows the distinction between pathogenic and nonpathogenic serotypes in foodstuff and isolates and specifically identifies the presence of Y. enterocolitica serotype O:3 (83, 85). NAAT methods have also been developed to distinguish Y. pseudotuberculosis from Y. enterocolitica and include O genotyping as well as virulence typing (83, 85).

Culture-independent NAATs are increasingly used to diagnose enteric disease and several platforms are available. A commercial multiplex bead-based assay, the xTAG gastrointestinal (GI) pathogen panel (Luminex Corporation), identifies the most common gastrointestinal pathogens, includingY. enterocolitica, directly from stool (86). Evaluations of this platform with clinical samples identified Y. enterocolitica in two specimens missed by conventional methods, whereas another study found that Y. enterocolitica was missed in two specimens positive by alternative NAAT targets (87, 88). The BioFire FilmArray gastrointestinal panel also includes a NAAT for Y. enterocolitica. Hitchcock et al. examined reproducibility of positive identification of rare pathogens with the BioFire FilmArray gastrointestinal panel; the study found that out of 50 stool samples with Y. enterocolitica, only 36 (72%) were reproducibly detected (89). Evaluation of the xTAG gastrointestinal pathogen panel and BioFire FilmArray gastrointestinal panel using 270 characterized stool samples demonstrated sensitivities for Y. enterocolitica of 48% and 100% and specificities of 100% and 100%, respectively (90). The QIAstat gastrointestinal panel detects 24 different pathogens from stool, including Y. enterocolitica; Hannet et al. reported 100% sensitivity (6 positive) and 100% specificity (379 negative) when testing stool samples (91). The rarity of yersiniosis has precluded robust evaluation of the culture-independent diagnostic test platforms through prospective studies, and retrospective (87) or spiked (contrived) stool specimens (92) have not typically included species other than Y. enterocolitica. Performance of the BioFire FilmArray gastrointestinal panel was assessed using spiked stool specimens determined to be negative by culture for the target organisms tested. The Yersinia panel used to spike specimens included 16 isolates of 9 Yersinia species. All three samples spiked with Y. enterocolitica tested positive; however, the three samples spiked with Y. frederiksenii and one of two samples spiked with Y. kristensenii also tested positive for Y. enterocolitica, indicating that the assay can cross-react with other Yersinia species (92, 93). FDA-cleared multiplex gastrointestinal panels that contain Y. enterocolitica as a target include the xTAG gastrointestinal pathogen panel, the BioFire FilmArray gastrointestinal panel, the Verigene enteric pathogen test, and the BD MAX extended enteric bacterial panel (90, 92, 93). Several multiplex NAATs have been validated and incorporated at public health labs within and outside the United States for detection of multiple gastrointestinal pathogens directly from stool; however, these assays detect only Y. enterocolitica (94–96). In 2018, the preliminary FoodNet report showed that the incidence of Yersinia infections reportedly increased 58% (0.9 per 100,000 population compared to 0.28 per 100,000 in 2015), likely because of increased NAAT use (36, 49). In Hampshire, United Kingdom, a similar finding was reported—the introduction of NAATs in 2016 resulted in an incidence of 13.8 Yersinia cases per 100,000 population from a historical low of 0.1 cases per 100 000 population per year (96).

sect1.title: Serratia
sect1.para: S. marcescens can be identified from positive blood culture bottles using commercially available, FDA-cleared multiplex NAATs, including the GenMark Diagnostic BCID-GN panel (www.genmarkdx.com), the Verigene BC-GN panel, the Accelerate Pheno panel (https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/cdrh_docs/reviews/K192665.pdf), and the BioFire FilmArray BCID2 panel (www.biofiredx.com). Respiratory pneumonia panels, including the BioFire pneumonia and Curetis Unyvero lower respiratory tract panels, have been FDA cleared for identification of S. marcescens from respiratory specimens (https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/cdrh_docs/reviews/K191967.pdf; https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cdrh/cfdocs/cfpmn/pmn.cfm?ID=K160068).

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Culture provides conclusive diagnosis of infection and is invaluable for public health surveillance systems and antimicrobial susceptibility testing.Yersiniaceae grow on most routine media present in the clinical laboratory, including blood, chocolate, and MacConkey agars incubated at 25 to 35°C for 24 to 48 h in ambient air. Incubation of Y. pseudotuberculosis and Y. enterocolitica cultures at 25°C is recommended due to the instability of the virulence plasmid at higher temperatures.

sect1.title: Yersinia
sect1.para: BecauseYersinia species grow more slowly than most Enterobacterales, selective medium should be used for culturing Yersinia species from nonsterile sources (e.g., stool and sputum) and environmental samples. Eosin-methylene blue, xylose-lysine-deoxycholate agar, and Hektoen enteric selective agars do not provide any advantage in the isolation of Yersinia species or in the differentiation of enteropathogenic Yersinia species from other organisms in the normal stool microbiota. Selective media for recovery of Yersinia species include cefsulodin-irgasan-novobiocin (CIN) agar, which inhibits the growth of many Enterobacterales, CHROMagar Yersinia, and salmonella-shigella-deoxycholate calcium chloride agar (97, 98). CIN agar provides better recovery rates for Yersinia than either MacConkey or salmonella-shigella agar incubated at room temperature. CHROMagar Yersinia has been shown to be as sensitive as CIN agar for the isolation of Y. enterocolitica, which may be useful for direct isolation of pathogenic strains from stool (98). Growth of many strains of Y. pseudotuberculosis can be inhibited on CIN agar due to cefsulodin and some strains of Y. enterocolitica biotype 3/O:3 to due to the CIN base. Similar recovery results were obtained with CHROMagar Yersinia enterocolitica, and therefore, MacConkey agar is preferred for isolation.

Recovery ofY. enterocolitica from food is more difficult than recovery from human clinical specimens and should be performed by a public health laboratory. Food must be enriched with saline (or a selective broth, such as modified Rappaport broth containing magnesium chloride, malachite green, and carbenicillin [MRB]) at cold temperatures for approximately 21 days (or 2 to 4 days in MRB) (99).

figure.title: FIGURE 1 (A and B) Y. enterocolitica (A) and Y. pseudotuberculosis (B) grown on sheep blood agar at 25°C for 72 h; (C) Y. pestis grown on sheep blood agar at 28°C for 72 h; (D) S. marcescens grown on sheep blood agar at 37°C for 24 h.

sect1.para: On sheep blood agar incubated at 25°C, well-isolated single colonies ofY. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis are about 0.5 to 1.0 mm and 3 to 4 mm after 24 and 72 h of growth, respectively (Fig. 1A and B). Y. enterocolitica colonies have a bull’s-eye appearance with a red center on CIN agar. Other members of the order Enterobacterales which grow on CIN agar, such as Serratia, Morganella, and Citrobacter species, produce colonies similar in appearance to those of Y. enterocolitica, but larger.

Y. pestis can be isolated from specimens from sterile sites on sheep blood agar (SBA). Although Y. pestis grows faster at 28°C, this may not be readily observable; on agar plates, Y. pestis colonies are typically the same size as at 37°C. For isolation of Y. pestis from contaminated specimens or nonsterile sources, including sputum samples, use of CIN agar is recommended (Fig. 2); inoculated plates should be incubated at 25 to 28°C. Y. pestis will grow in blood culture bottles; whole blood should be directly inoculated into aerobic blood culture bottles and incubated on continuous monitoring systems at 35 to 37°C, with subsequent culture of blood culture-positive specimens on blood agar. Although data from plague patients are very limited, a 1- to 2-day time to positivity has been reported with commercial blood culture systems (22, 100). If plague is suspected, blood cultures should be incubated for up to 7 days to allow time for growth of Y. pestis (47).

Y. pestis colonies are ~1 and 1.5 mm in diameter, with irregular edges, gray-white to opaque, after 48 h of incubation on SBA and 3 to 4 mm after 72 h of incubation (Fig. 1C). No hemolysis is seen on blood agar. After 48 to 72 h, a fried-egg appearance is observed, with the center of the colonies being more opaque (Fig. 1C). Y. pestis grows more slowly on MacConkey agar, and colonies are only pinpoint size as well as colorless (non-lactose fermenter) after 48 h of growth. On CIN agar, Y. pestis colonies have a red center (Fig. 2B). Growth of Y. pestis is slower on CIN than SBA.

sect1.title: Serratia, Ewingella, and Rahnella
sect1.para: Serratia, Ewingella, and Rahnella species grow well on standard nutrient agar, including TSA with 5% SBA and MacConkey agar at 30 to 37°C (7, 41). Serratia species will also grow in blood culture bottles (101). Ewingella and Rahnella are psychrotolerant and will grow at 4°C. S. marcescens does not grow at 4°C, whereas most other Serratia species will. Clinical isolates of S. marcescens are often nonpigmented, whereas environmental isolates tend to be red pigmented (7) (Fig. 1D). Non-pigmented Serratia isolates are typically 2 mm after 24 h of incubation, round with entire margins, opaque, and greyish white. Colonies of S. odorifera and S. ficaria give off a potato-like odor (7).

Serratia species will grow on BBL CHROMagar. CHROMagar-Serratia (CHROMagar, Paris, France) is a commercially available selective medium, specifically developed for detection and isolation of S. marcescens. S. marcescens colonies are green-blue to metallic blue on this medium, which allows their differentiation from other Gram-negative organisms (102).

sect1.title: Yersinia
sect1.para: Yersinia species are catalase positive and oxidase negative and ferment glucose. Y. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis can be presumptively identified by reactions on triple sugar iron and lysine iron agar slants. Y. enterocolitica produces a yellow color in the entire triple sugar iron tube without gas production due to sucrose (slant) and glucose (butt) fermentation, and Y. pseudotuberculosis produces an alkaline slant and an acid butt, like Shigella species. Both species are lysine decarboxylase negative and therefore produce a yellow butt in lysine iron agar slants. Yersinia species, including Y. pestis, are included in the databases of some automated biochemical identification systems; however, most databases were established with only a few Yersinia isolates. Automated systems may not adequately identify Yersinia species due in part to their slow growth and biochemical inactivity. API 20E was shown to have the highest sensitivity and specificity for identification of Y. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis (103).

figure.title: FIGURE 2 Contaminated bubo aspirate plated on both SBA (A) and CIN agar (B). Note the multiple colony types seen on SBA and pure isolated colonies of Y. pestis on CIN.

sect1.para: Identification of suspectedY. pestis isolates in the clinical laboratory is based on the detection of small Gram-negative bacilli (0.5 by 1 to 2 μm) which are catalase positive and oxidase and urease negative and display the following growth characteristics after 48 h: 1- to 1.5-mm gray-white irregular colonies on blood agar after growth and non-lactose-fermenting, pinpoint colonies on MacConkey agar. See “Sentinel Level Clinical Microbiology Laboratory Guidelines” on the American Society for Microbiology website (https://asm.org/ASM/media/Policy-and-Advocacy/LRN/Y-pestis-fixed-figures.pdf) for Y. pestis-specific guidance. If Y. pestis is suspected, samples should immediately be sent to a reference laboratory that can confirm (or rule out) its identification. In the United States, all states have at least one LRN reference laboratory that can identify bacterial select agents, including Y. pestis. See also www.emergency.cdc.gov/lrn. The WHO Collaborating Centers for Y. pestis can also provide guidance and diagnostic testing. Rapid diagnosis and treatment are essential to reduce mortality associated with Y. pestis infection. 16S rRNA gene sequencing can provide a genus-level identification, and isolates identified by this method should be referred to an LRN reference laboratory if Y. pestis is suspected.

Isolates can be identified asY. pestis in reference laboratories via bacteriophage lysis as well as molecular methods, including NAATs (e.g., PCR); testing is available in LRN reference laboratories. 16S rRNA gene sequencing should not be used as the sole diagnostic test to identify Y. pestis isolates, due to the inability to distinguish Y. pestis from Y. pseudotuberculosis.

Automated biochemical systems may misidentify isolates ofY. pestis due to its slow growth and the limited Y. pestis databases available with many of these systems. Misidentifications of Y. pestis human isolates have included Acinetobacter lwoffii using MicroScan, Pseudomonas luteola and Y. pseudotuberculosis using Vitek 2, and Y. pseudotuberculosis using Phoenix (22, 81, 100). Because of these limitations, a high level of suspicion on the part of clinical microbiologists is essential. Results from automated identification systems should be analyzed critically in the clinical laboratory, taking into consideration the reliability of these systems for accurate identification of slow-growing, rare, or biothreat organisms (81, 100). Potential indications of misidentification include a low probability or confidence value and an identification of a pathogen inconsistent with the clinical or microbiological picture.

Y. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis can be most easily differentiated from Y. pestis by urease activity (strongly positive at 25°C; positive at 37°C) and motility (25°C), both of which are negative for Y. pestis (Table 1). Because of the risk for aerosol exposure for Y. pestis, the slide motility test is not recommended; motility agar should be utilized. Y. enterocolitica can be differentiated from other Yersinia species, since it typically does not utilize citrate or produce pyrazinamidase (except in 1A strains), nor does it ferment mucate or rhamnose; however, it does ferment sucrose (Table 1). Y. pseudotuberculosis differs from other Yersinia species (non-Y. pestis) by a negative ornithine decarboxylase test. Identification of other Yersinia species can be performed by biochemical analysis (Table 1) (104).

Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) (MALDI Biotyper system [Bruker] and Vitek-MS [bioMérieux]) shows potential for the identification ofYersinia isolates (105–107). MALDI-TOF MS identification is rapid, and its cost is low (<1 U.S. dollar/identification). As with other identification systems, a limitation is that it requires a database of well-characterized reference strains to avert misidentifications or no identification. The FDA-cleared Vitek MS (V3.2) and MALDI Biotyper (V11) reference libraries contain Y. enterocolitica, Y. pseudotuberculosis, Y. frederiksenii, Y. intermedia, and Y. kristensenii. Species and biotype identification by MALDI-TOF MS has been demonstrated for pathogenic and nonpathogenic biotypes of Y. enterocolitica (108, 109). The lack of Y. pestis in FDA-approved in vitro diagnostic databases for commercial MALDI-TOF MS systems results in the inability to differentiate Y. pestis and Y. pseudotuberculosis and misidentification of Y. pestis as Y. pseudotuberculosis (77, 107, 110). Similar results were obtained when research-use-only databases from the same manufacturers were utilized. Misidentification of a Y. pseudotuberculosis isolate as Y. pestis by MALDI-TOF MS in a clinical laboratory has also been documented (111). Safety considerations in target preparation for MALDI-TOF MS analysis must be considered. An ethanol-formic acid tube extraction procedure inactivates Y. pestis more reliably than direct colony or on-plate formic acid extraction (110).

Development and evaluation of more robust commercial spectral databases for differentiatingYersinia species are needed for high-confidence identifications using MALDI-TOF MS in the clinical laboratory. To date, data are lacking with respect to the accuracy of identification of Yersinia species other than Y. enterocolitica, Y. pseudotuberculosis, and Y. pestis. Due to the lack of Y. pestis data in commercially available databases and poor differentiation of Y. pseudotuberculosis and Y. pestis with research-use-only databases, a MALDI-TOF MS identification of a Yersinia species should be confirmed by other laboratory tests. As mentioned with regard to other automated identification systems, laboratorians should consider the limitations of the database being used, the clinical and microbiological picture associated with the isolate, and the confidence value associated with the identification.

sect1.title: Serratia, Ewingella, and Rahnella
sect1.para: Serratia, Ewingella, and Rahnella species ferment glucose, are oxidase negative, reduce nitrate to nitrite, and are Voges-Proskauer positive. Other biochemical properties are indicated in Table 2. Phenotypic systems such as the API 20e strip (bioMérieux), the Vitek 2 assay (bioMérieux), and the BD Phoenix test (BD Diagnostics, Sparks, MD) have been used to accurately identify several Serratia species (7). Serratia species correctly identified by Vitek MS (bioMérieux) automated systems include S. fonticola, S. liquefaciens, and S. marcescens. Ewingella americana was identified to the species level using the MALDI-TOF Vitek MS platform (bioMérieux) (112).

sect1.title: Typing Systems
sect1.para: Biochemical, serological, and molecular methods can be used to further differentiate isolates within a givenYersinia species and are particularly useful for epidemiologic analyses to assess pathogenesis and geographic distribution of different strains. Y. enterocolitica has six biotypes, 1A, 1B, 2, 3, 4, and 5, which can be differentiated based on reactivity to esculin, indole, D-xylose, trehalose, pyrazinamidase, β-D-glucosidase, and lipase (Table 4). Although biotype 1A strains are recovered from human stool specimens, this biotype is thought to be nonpathogenic because it lacks the virulence plasmid pYV and major chromosomal virulence genes identified in other Yersinia strains. However, this biotype has been implicated in foodborne outbreaks, and other lines of evidence, including production of enterotoxin, survival in macrophages, and invasion of epithelial cells in vitro, suggest that it is capable of causing disease in humans (113). Biotypes 1B and 2 through 5 are pathogenic. Strains belonging to biotype 1A can be differentiated from the others by salicin and pyrazinamidase positivity (Table 4) (114). Serotyping shows an association with the pathogenicity of the isolate, and only a small number of the >70 known serotypes are routinely recovered from human clinical specimens. Only two antisera are readily available; more comprehensive serotyping of Y. enterocolitica may be performed at the CDC (Atlanta, GA) upon request. Other methods that have been evaluated to determine the pathogenicity of Y. enterocolitica are based on the presence of the virulence plasmid and include autoagglutination, calcium-dependent growth at 37°C, and pigmentation on Congo red. Selective media containing Congo red as well as PCR assays have been evaluated for differentiation of virulent from avirulent strains but are currently used only in research laboratories (84).

For distinguishing individual strains withinYersinia species, molecular typing methods, including pulsed-field gel electrophoresis, have long been used. As whole-genome sequencing has become more commonplace, comparative approaches using an organism’s whole-genome sequence for strain typing have been developed (65, 115). Recently, a core genome multilocus sequence typing scheme was developed for species identification and strain characterization of Yersinia species using whole-genome sequence data (65). Average nucleotide identity was also calculated for the Yersinia species by Savin et al., who showed at a genomic level that Y. pestis and Y. pseudotuberculosis cannot be easily differentiated; in a core genome phylogeny, Y. pestis is a subcluster of Y. pseudotuberculosis, which is expected, since Y. pestis has emerged as a clone of Y. pseudotuberculosis (65). A whole-genome multilocus sequence typing method has been developed for Y. pestis using well-defined isolates to demonstrate that the method is able to accurately distinguish epidemiologically linked and unlinked isolates (115). Case investigations have further demonstrated the utility of this whole-genome multilocus sequence typing method to definitively link isolates from human cases and environmental sources (animals and fleas) to identify the source of the infection and demonstrate Y. pestis strain diversity during an epizootic (115–117). This method provides more resolution than pulsed-field gel electrophoresis, because it compares sequence differences across every gene in the Y. pestis genome (115). Whole-genome sequence typing of Y. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis has been proposed as a powerful tool for outbreak surveillance, but standardized methods have yet to be published (28, 65, 118, 119).

table.title: TABLE 4 Reactions of biotypes of Y. enterocolitica after incubation at 25°C for 48 h

sect1.para: a+, ≥90% of strains are positive; d, 11 to 89% of strains are positive; −, ≥90% of strains are negative; (+), weakly positive reaction.

Molecular approaches for typingSerratia species have focused on S. marcescens due to its association with health care associated infections that can be traced to environmental sources within the health care setting (120). Studies utilizing molecular epidemiological approaches for outbreak strains have utilized whole-genome sequencing to link outbreak strains and provide information about the antimicrobial resistance potential of individual strains (121, 122). In the absence of cultured strains, amplicon sequencing of discriminatory genomic loci has been utilized to identify point sources of outbreak strains in environmental sources such as hospital sinks (123).

sect1.title: Yersinia
sect1.para: Streptomycin, tetracyclines, ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin are FDA approved for the treatment of plague. Treatment recommendations for naturally acquired infections and bioterrorism responses are contained in reference124. The Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (www.clsi.org) has published interpretative criteria and quality control limits for antimicrobial susceptibility testing of Y. pestis (125). Antimicrobial susceptibility testing of Y. pestis is not performed in clinical microbiology laboratories because of safety concerns regarding working with this organism and lack of resistance to antimicrobials used for treatment of naturally occurring plague outside the United States.

Antimicrobial resistance among isolates ofY. pestis has never been documented in the United States and only very rarely elsewhere (126). No resistance was observed in 392 Y. pestis isolates from 17 countries (214 were from the United States, isolated from 1971 to 2009) against eight antimicrobials (gentamicin, streptomycin, tetracycline, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, chloramphenicol, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) used for treatment or prophylaxis of plague (126). Single-drug resistance to frontline therapeutics in Y. pestis isolates has infrequently been reported from Madagascar, Mongolia, and China (1995 to 2000) (127–130). Susceptibility testing of hundreds of patient isolates from Madagascar failed to identify multidrug resistance since initial detection of an isolate with this property in the 1990s (126, 129, 131).

Most cases ofY. enterocolitica gastroenteritis do not require treatment; however, treatment is necessary in cases of systemic disease, especially in immunosuppressed patients. Treatment options include fluoroquinolones. Y. enterocolitica has rarely been isolated from patients with infective endocarditis, but in these cases, resistance to aminopenicillins was estimated to be 71%; recommended treatment includes a third-generation cephalosporin or a combination fluoroquinolone with an aminoglycoside (56). Y. enterocolitica produces two β-lactamases, one of which is a class A constitutive enzyme and the other of which is an inducible class C enzyme that is not inhibited by traditional β-lactamase inhibitors. Although the β-lactamase confers resistance to penicillin on Y. enterocolitica, the organism remains susceptible to the extended-spectrum cephalosporins. Resistance to fluoroquinolones is due to either a mutation in the gyrA gene or efflux mechanisms. In a study conducted in Spain, 23% of Y. enterocolitica strains isolated from patients with gastroenteritis were nalidixic acid resistant. All resistant isolates had a mutation in gyrA, and some were resistant based on an efflux mechanism as well (132). Y. enterocolitica strains are susceptible in vitro to aminoglycosides, chloramphenicol, fluoroquinolones, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, tetracycline, and third-generation cephalosporins (56, 133, 134). Y. enterocolitica strains display resistance to penicillin, aminopenicillins and first-generation cephalosporins as a result of chromosomal beta-lactamase-encoding genes (blaA and blaB) (56). Karlsson et al. (135) reported the first multidrug-resistant Y. enterocolitica 4/O:3 strain, which was isolated from fresh spinach during a 2019 foodborne outbreak that occurred in Sweden. Their study confirmed the presence of resistance elements in Yersinia encoded on transposon Tn2670, which was originally discovered in outbreak isolates of Enterobacteriaceae that had IncFII plasmids; additionally, a single isolate contained a tetB-Rep plasmid similar to a Pasteurellaceae tetB-Rep plasmid. Outbreak strains were generally resistant to ampicillin, erythromycin, fusidic acid, rifampin, chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and sulfamethoxazole; one strain with the tetB-Rep plasmid also displayed resistance to tetracycline (135). Y. pseudotuberculosis is susceptible to ampicillin, tetracycline, chloramphenicol, cephalosporins, and aminoglycosides. Although self-limiting infections due to Y. pseudotuberculosis are not usually treated, patients with septicemia should be treated with ampicillin, streptomycin, or tetracycline. Multidrug-resistant (MDR) strains of Y. pseudotuberculosis have rarely been reported (136). Cabanel et al. reported three strains of Y. pseudotuberculosis (two environmental and one clinical) that were MDR and contained either a conjugative plasmid of the IncN group or a plasmid of the IncHI2 group which have been previously found in Enterobacterales (136).

sect1.title: Serratia, Ewingella, and Rahnella
sect1.para: Resistant strains ofS. marcescens are a hallmark of nosocomial outbreaks in compromised and critically ill patients. Serratia species are intrinsically resistant to narrow-spectrum penicillins, macrolides, clindamycin, linezolid, glycopeptides, and rifampin (7). In addition, most Serratia species are resistant to ampicillin, amoxicillin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, ampicillin-sulbactam, narrow-spectrum cephalosporins, cephamycins, cefuroxime, nitrofurantoin, and colistin (7). Serratia species are often susceptible to aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones, although resistance has been reported. Carbapenemase-producing strains of S. marcescens have been described (137, 138). A recent survey of Gram-negative blood culture results from 24 U.S. clinical laboratories that used the GenMark Dx ePlex for identification and characterization of β-lactamase and carbapenemase production identified a prevalence of 0.6% for extended-spectrum-β-lactamase (blaCTX-M)- or carbapenemase-producing S. marcescens strains (139). Some carbapenemase-producing strains of S. marcescens also displayed an MDR phenotype affecting various antimicrobials, including fluoroquinolones and aminoglycosides (137).

E. americana strains are frequently resistant to several classes of antimicrobial agents. Most strains of E. americana and R. aquatilis are generally susceptible to aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (45, 140, 141).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Isolation of a small Gram-negative bacillus (0.5 by 1 to 2 μm) that grows slowly at 37°C on blood agar (pinpoint, gray-white colonies after 24 h), is a non-lactose fermenter on MacConkey agar (pinpoint colonies after 48 h), and is oxidase negative, catalase positive, and urease negative should be strongly suspected asY. pestis and immediately referred to an LRN reference laboratory. A positive test result for a primary clinical specimen via detection of F1 antigen or by NAAT, provides a presumptive diagnosis of Y. pestis. A single positive serum antibody sample is also considered presumptive evidence of plague. Confirmation of Y. pestis infection includes (i) identification of a culture as Y. pestis or (ii) a 4-fold difference in titer of serum antibody to Y. pestis F1 antigen in acute- and convalescent-phase serum samples. Isolation of Y. pestis from any human specimen is clinically significant and warrants further investigation. The sources most likely to yield Y. pestis are sputum, bubo (lymph node) aspirate, and blood. Due to the lack of accuracy of commercial systems for the identification of Y. pestis, the potential use of Y. pestis as a bioweapon, and the seriousness of the disease, specimens from suspected plague cases should be sent to a local public health laboratory for confirmation. Any MALDI-TOF MS, 16S rRNA gene sequencing, or shotgun metagenomic sequence-based identification of Y. pestis should be referred to reference laboratories (LRN reference laboratories in the United States) for Y. pestis-specific testing.

In the United States, plague is a nationally notifiable disease, andY. pestis is classified as a tier 1 select agent. Laboratories identifying an organism as Y. pestis are required to notify the Select Agent Program within 24 h and submit a Form 4 within 7 calendar days. Report forms, contact information, laboratory registration information, and pertinent citations of the U.S. Federal Code can be found at https://www.selectagents.gov.

Isolation of enteropathogenicYersinia species from stool is not sufficient for causal evidence of disease, since nonpathogenic strains may be part of the normal stool microbiota. Isolation of Yersinia species in pure culture from a symptomatic patient with no other diagnosis should be considered suspect. Isolation of Yersinia species from blood or other normally sterile sites should also be considered significant. Reporting of enteropathogenic Yersinia is not nationally notifiable, so the actual incidence of disease could be underreported. The CDC monitors the frequency of yersiniosis cases through the Foodborne Disease Active Surveillance Network (FoodNet) (https://www.cdc.gov/foodnet/index.html).

It has not been shown to be cost-effective to screen all stools forY. enterocolitica by using CIN agar (142). Isolation rates vary based on geographic locations, with the highest incidence in temperate regions, so the decision to routinely rule out these organisms in stool cultures should be evaluated in individual laboratories after consultation with the infectious disease physicians.

Due to their rarity, diagnosis ofYersinia species is challenging, particularly for Y. pestis and Y. pseudotuberculosis. Clinical laboratories are encouraged to consult reference laboratories if a Yersinia species is cultured or identified.
Accurate and rapid diagnosis ofS. marcescens in outbreak settings is important for environmental remediation to prevent further cases.
